here's 2 more i thought of. feel free to ignore them if they're stupid:

4) Challenge vs reward
  if there is too much money in an easy scenario or too little in a hard 
one. for "reward scenarios" which give you a lot of money at the end of a 
Champaign for doing the whole campaign (by campaign i mean a group of 
scenarios like the tevfifty) this could be stretched but you might want to 
begin with a teleporter maze that the last scenario tells you how to get 
through so no-one just skips to the $$$ scenario

5)make them interesting and not just impossible
  if it's just monsters banging they're heads against you and nothing for 
you to do but hit the fire key this get a bad rating (or level or number or 
whatever) but if you actually make choices by having different goals or 
different means of achieving a goal or if there is something that makes the 
scenario unique then this gets a good, um, thing. if everyone makes 50 of 
these levels then we'll run out of ideas so if anywhere between 1/3 and 2/3 
of ones scenarios are like this that suffices

well that's it, just giving my ideas,

From: "Daniel Paul Hightower" <dph_of_rules@...>
Reply-To: gladiator@yahoogroups.com
To: gladiator@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [gladiator] Evaluation of scenarios
Date: Wed, 23 May 2001 18:41:25 -0000

As promised, I am getting around to something.

I propose that we evaluate sets of scenarios [15 or fewer and/or where
the author provides a description of each scenario] using the
following factors to evaluate individual scenarios:

1)internal navigability - ability to walk around in a scenario without
getting lost - only 2 examples of sceanrios that don't match this
criteria, 'The Stairs' from tevfifty and 'The Cellars' from tevfifty.

2)mobility - wide enough spaces to allow either a large slime or a
fire elemental go through fairly easily.  biggest examles of one that
doesn't fit: 'The Labrinth"

3)quirks - negative factors.   for example, in most of my scenarios,
chain lightning can't be used without waiting forever.

If there are more factors for evaluation of individual scenarios, let
us add them.
What I propose doing for large sets of scenarios is voting in a poll
[after the scenarios are completely debugged] on existing factors plus
a few more such as ability to produce a theme.  Afterall, what keeps
this game going right now is creation of new scenarios and rating new
scenarios we go appears to be beneficial.
